metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: JavaScript Const
The const keyword was introduced in ES6 (2015)
content.html: The const keyword was introduced in ES6 (2015)

content.text: Variables defined with const cannot be Redeclared
content.html: Variables defined with const cannot be Redeclared

content.text: Variables defined with const cannot be Reassigned
content.html: Variables defined with const cannot be Reassigned

content.text: Variables defined with const have Block Scope
content.html: Variables defined with const have Block Scope

content.text: Cannot be Reassigned
A variable defined with the const keyword cannot be reassigned:
content.html: A variable defined with the const keyword cannot be reassigned:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // This will also give an error

syntax_highlighting.text: // This will also give an error

content.code_html:
const PI = 3.141592653589793;
PI = 3.14;      // This will give an error
 PI = PI + 10;   // This will also give an error

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // This will also give an error

content.text: Must be Assigned
JavaScript const variables must be assigned a value when they are declared:
content.html: JavaScript const variables must be assigned a value when they are declared:

content.code_html: const PI = 3.14159265359;

const PI;
PI = 3.14159265359;

content.text: When to use JavaScript const?
Always declare a variable with const when you know that the value should not be changed.
content.html: Always declare a variable with const when you know that the value should not be changed.

content.text: Use const when you declare:
content.html: Use const when you declare:

content.text: Constant Objects and Arrays
The keyword const is a little misleading.
content.html: The keyword const is a little misleading.

content.text: It does not define a constant value. It defines a constant reference to a value.
content.html: It does not define a constant value. It defines a constant reference to a value.

content.text: Because of this you can NOT:
content.html: Because of this you can NOT:

content.text: But you CAN:
content.html: But you CAN:

content.text: Constant Arrays
You can change the elements of a constant array:
content.html: You can change the elements of a constant array:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // You can create a constant array:

syntax_highlighting.text: // You can create a constant array:

content.code_html:
// You can create a constant array:
 const cars = ["Saab", "Volvo", "BMW"];

// You can change an element:
 cars[0] = "Toyota";

// You can add an element:
 cars.push("Audi");

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // You can create a constant array:

content.text: But you can NOT reassign the array:
content.html: But you can NOT reassign the array:

content.code_html:
const cars = ["Saab", "Volvo", "BMW"];

cars = ["Toyota", "Volvo", "Audi"];    // ERROR

content.text: Constant Objects
You can change the properties of a constant object:
content.html: You can change the properties of a constant object:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // You can create a const object:

syntax_highlighting.text: // You can create a const object:

content.code_html:
// You can create a const object:
 const car = {type:"Fiat", model:"500", color:"white"};

// You can change a property:
 car.color = "red";

// You can add a property:
 car.owner = "Johnson";

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // You can create a const object:

content.text: But you can NOT reassign the object:
content.html: But you can NOT reassign the object:

content.code_html:
const car = {type:"Fiat", model:"500", color:"white"};

car = {type:"Volvo", model:"EX60", color:"red"};    // ERROR

content.text: Difference Between var, let and const
What is Good?
let and const have block scope .
content.html: let and const have block scope.

content.text: let and const can not be redeclared .
content.html: let and const can not be redeclared.

content.text: let and const must be declared before use.
content.html: let and const must be declared before use.

content.text: let and const does not bind to this .
content.html: let and const does not bind to this.

content.text: let and const are not hoisted .
content.html: let and const are not hoisted.

content.text: What is Not Good?
var does not have to be declared.
content.html: var does not have to be declared.

content.text: var is hoisted.
content.html: var is hoisted.

content.text: var binds to this.
content.html: var binds to this.

content.text: Browser Support
The let and const keywords are not supported in Internet Explorer 11 or earlier.
content.html: The let and const keywords are not supported in Internet Explorer 11 or earlier.

content.text: The following table defines the first browser versions with full support:
content.html: The following table defines the first browser versions with full support:

content.code_html:
Chrome 49 Edge 12 Firefox 36 Safari 11 Opera 36
Mar, 2016 Jul, 2015 Jan, 2015 Sep, 2017 Mar, 2016

content.text: Block Scope
Declaring a variable with const is similar to let when it comes to Block Scope .
content.html: Declaring a variable with const is similar to let when it comes to Block Scope.

content.text: The x declared in the block, in this example, is not the same as the x declared outside the block:
content.html: The x declared in the block, in this example, is not the same as the x declared outside the block:

content.code_html:
const x = 10;
// Here x is 10
{
const x = 2;
// Here x is 2
}

// Here x is 10

content.text: You can learn more about block scope in the chapter JavaScript Scope .
content.html: You can learn more about block scope in the chapter JavaScript Scope.

content.text: Redeclaring
Redeclaring a JavaScript var variable is allowed anywhere in a program:
content.html: Redeclaring a JavaScript var variable is allowed anywhere in a program:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
var x = 2;     // Allowed
var x = 3;     // Allowed
  x = 4;         // Allowed

content.code:
var x = 2;     // Allowed
var x = 3;     // Allowed
x = 4;         // Allowed

syntax_highlighting.text:
var x = 2;     // Allowed
var x = 3;     // Allowed
  x = 4;         // Allowed

content.code_html:
var x = 2;     // Allowed
 var x = 3;     // Allowed
 x = 4;         // Allowed

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
var x = 2;     // Allowed
var x = 3;     // Allowed
  x = 4;         // Allowed

content.text: Redeclaring an existing var or let variable to const , in the same scope, is not allowed:
content.html: Redeclaring an existing var or let variable to const, in the same scope, is not allowed:

content.code_html:
var x = 2;     // Allowed
 const x = 2;   // Not allowed
{
let x = 2;     // Allowed
 const x = 2;   // Not allowed
}

{
const x = 2;   // Allowed
 const x = 2;   // Not allowed
 }

content.text: Reassigning an existing const variable, in the same scope, is not allowed:
content.html: Reassigning an existing const variable, in the same scope, is not allowed:

content.code_html:
const x = 2;     // Allowed
 x = 2;           // Not allowed
 var x = 2;       // Not allowed
 let x = 2;       // Not allowed
 const x = 2;     // Not allowed
{
  const x = 2;   // Allowed
   x = 2;         // Not allowed
  var x = 2;     // Not allowed
  let x = 2;     // Not allowed
   const x = 2;   // Not allowed
 }

content.text: Redeclaring a variable with const , in another scope, or in another block, is allowed:
content.html: Redeclaring a variable with const, in another scope, or in another block, is allowed:

content.code_html:
const x = 2;       // Allowed

{
  const x = 3;   // Allowed
 }

{
  const x = 4;   // Allowed
 }

content.text: Hoisting
Variables defined with var are hoisted to the top and can be initialized at any time.
content.html: Variables defined with var are hoisted to the top and can be initialized at any time.

content.text: Meaning: You can use the variable before it is declared:
content.html: Meaning: You can use the variable before it is declared:

content.code_html:
carName = "Volvo";
var carName;

content.text: If you want to learn more about hoisting, study the chapter JavaScript Hoisting .
content.html: If you want to learn more about hoisting, study the chapter JavaScript Hoisting.

content.text: Variables defined with const are also hoisted to the top, but not initialized.
content.html: Variables defined with const are also hoisted to the top, but not initialized.

content.text: Meaning: Using a const variable before it is declared will result in a ReferenceError :
content.html: Meaning: Using a const variable before it is declared will result in a ReferenceError:

content.code_html:
alert (carName);
const carName = "Volvo";

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
True or False. Variables created with the const keyword can never change their value.
content.html:
True or False.
Variables created with the const keyword can never change their value.

metadata.question: True or False.Variables created with the const keyword can never change their value.

content.question: True or False.Variables created with the const keyword can never change their value.
